net.jakubholy.dbunitexpress
Class AbstractEmbeddedDbTestCase

java.lang.Object
  junit.framework.Assert
      junit.framework.TestCase
          org.dbunit.DatabaseTestCase
              org.dbunit.DBTestCase
                  net.jakubholy.dbunitexpress.AbstractEmbeddedDbTestCase
All Implemented Interfaces:
junit.framework.Test
public abstract class AbstractEmbeddedDbTestCase
extends org.dbunit.DBTestCase

Parent class for DbUnit test cases that want to use an embedded (Derby) database for testing instead of an external standalone DB in few easy steps. It replaces the DBTestCase. Such tests are useful for testing classes that interact with a database.

This class itself doesn't do anything more than delegating to an EmbeddedDbTester and it only exists for convenience and backward compatibility. See JavaDoc of that class to learn how to use it and how to set up your database unit tests. See DbUnit_Test_Skeleton subproject of jeeutils at SourceForge

Author:
jholy
See Also:
EmbeddedDbTester, DatabaseCreator.main(String[])

Method Detail

getDataSet

protected org.dbunit.dataset.IDataSet getDataSet()
                                          throws Exception
Override if you want to load data from another file or files or if you want to use different format of the data set (e.g. FlatXmlDataSet).

Warning: Once you override this, you will not be able to access the original data set, both super.getDataSet() and getEmbeddedDbTester().getDataSet() will return the data set you've created. You can access it as follows 


 getEmbeddedDbTester().createDataSetFromFile(EmbeddedDbTester.DBUNIT_TEST_DATA_SET_NAME);

You may use EmbeddedDbTester.createDataSetFromFile(String) to create a data set from a file stored in the default location like this: return getEmbeddedDbTester().createDataSetFromFile("your_data_set.xml");

Specified by:
getDataSet in class org.dbunit.DatabaseTestCase
Throws:
Exception
See Also:
DatabaseTestCase.getDataSet()

replaceDatabase

protected final void replaceDatabase(String dataSetFile)
                              throws FileNotFoundException,
                                     org.dbunit.DatabaseUnitRuntimeException,
                                     org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException
Replace the content of the database from the provided data set XML file. This is useful e.g. if, for a particular test method, you need some special data in the database and you don't want to create a new test class for that. This method does the same database re-initialization that happens in DatabaseTestCase.setUp().

Consider this to be an experimental method that may have yet undiscovered side effects on DbUnit's state and behavior and use at your own risk.

Usage example


 public void testFetchData_emtpyTable() throws Exception {
                this.replaceDatabase("TestData/empty_data_set.xml");
                // Call the tested method
                final List data = this.target.fetchData();
                // Verify results
                assertEquals("empty data set => shall be empty", 0, data.size());
 }

 // other test method may use the default data set w/o calling replaceDatabase

Parameters:
dataSetFile - (required) File name of a DbUnit Data Set XML
Throws:
FileNotFoundException - If the provided string isn't an existing file's name
org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException
org.dbunit.DatabaseUnitRuntimeException
See Also:
IEnhancedDatabaseTester.replaceDatabase(String)

replaceDatabase

protected final void replaceDatabase(org.dbunit.dataset.IDataSet newDataSet)
                              throws org.dbunit.DatabaseUnitRuntimeException
See replaceDatabase(String) for detailed description, here we only describe the differences.

This variant replaces the data by the provided Data Set - which may be constructed programmatically - instead of loading them from a .xml file.

Example


 import org.dbunit.dataset.*;
 import org.dbunit.dataset.datatype.DataType;

 final DefaultTable table = new DefaultTable("my_test_schema.my_test_table", new Column[]{
                        new Column("id", DataType.INTEGER)
                        , new Column("some_text", DataType.VARCHAR) });
 table.addRow( new Object[] {new Integer(1), "hello!"} );

 final DefaultDataSet dataSet = new DefaultDataSet(table);
 this.replaceDatabase( dataSet );

Parameters:
newDataSet - (required) the data set used to replace the data with
Throws:
org.dbunit.DatabaseUnitRuntimeException - thrown by IDatabaseTester.onSetup()
See Also:
IEnhancedDatabaseTester.replaceDatabase(IDataSet)

clearTable

protected final void clearTable(String tableName)
                         throws SQLException
Removes all data from the given test table. This is useful e.g. if you want to verify that your code behaves correctly when there are no data.

Parameters:
tableName - Table name in the form used by the underlying tester, i.e. either fully qualified (schema.table) or unqualified (only table) - likely same as in your data set XML file
Throws:
SQLException
See Also:
IEnhancedDatabaseTester.clearTable(String)
